VOL. XIX, NO.

BALTIMORE, MD., JANUARY 11, 1915.

12.

BOB LAYfIELD TAKEN HOME

BASEBALL PLANS ARE LAID
NEW TEAM ADVISERS

Varsity Quarterback With Broken Back
Removed From Hopkins Hospital
to "His Own Room at Home."

Committee in Charge of This Sport
Met Friday to Approve Schedule and
Talk Over Selection of Coach.

"Plucky Bob," the 'Varsity quarterback whose spinal cord was
broken in the football game with
Lehigh last October, was removed
from the Johns Hopkins Hospital
Thursday night to his home in Wilmington, Del.
For weeks it has been his most
cherished hope that he might be
taken to his home, where he could
be constantly with his parents and
where, he felt, he could more effectively fight the battle for his life.
Dr. Roland T. Abercrombie and
Dr. William S. Baer made a thorough examination of the game little
patient and decided that whenever
Bob wanted to he might safely
make the journey to Wilmington.
And so, in accordance with the
wishes of Bob and his parents, the
trip was started almost immediately. The patient was carried on
his bed to the hospital automobile
ambulance and, accompanied by Dr.
Abercrombie and Mr. Layfield, was
driven carefully to Union Station.
Here Bob and his bed were put
in a baggage car. The train left
at 8.10 P. M., and though every
jolt and turn of the hour and a
half's ride must have been felt by
the patient, Bob was the most
cheerful person in the party. The
thought that he was going home
was enough to keep up his spirits
and to help him endure the hardships of the journey.
Dr. Abercrombie said, in speaking of the trip to Wilmington:"Mr.
Layfield and I accompanied Bob on
the journey to Wilmington. He
stood the trip as well as could be
expected of one in his condition.
Although there is practically no
hope for his recovery, Bob and his
whole family have kept up the most
remarkable spirit I have ever seen.
Not one of them has shown a sign
that he has given up hope, or that
he has any intention of doing anything but keeping up a good spirit
and fighting to help Bob live.
"Such spirit and gameness as Bob
has shown in his remarkable struggle for existence deserves the highest reward, and to Bob that reward
would be life itself. And now, as
he lies in his own room, there with
him lie the prayers and sympathies
of every Hopkins student and of
every one of his host of friends in
Baltimore."
Bob had been in a room in the
Marburg Building of Johns Hopkins Hospital since November 3.
At first it was thought that he never
would have enough strength to be
removed, but a surprising courage
and reserve strength permitted the

'Varsity Baseball Committee
met Friday afternoon in the Hopkins Club to make plans for the
coming season. The schedule and
the matter of selecting a coach were
the chief topics discussed by the
Board, which is composed of Dr.
Thomas R. Brown, Dr. Robert B.
Roulston and Attorney Robertson
Griswold, alumni advisors; Dr.
Ronald T. Abercrombie, director of
athletics; Capt. C. C. Porter, Graduate Manager G. E. Dorsey and
Manager J. S. Short.
Eight or nine games will be
played this spring, the first being
with Princeton on April i at Homewood. In addition, most of the
State college teams will be met.
Contests also will be booked with
Swarthmore and University of
Pittsburgh. Nearly all of the games
will be on Saturday at Homewood,
only one trip being in view at this
time. The tentative schedule drawn
up by the manager was approved
and will be completed within the
next two weeks.
The committee decided to select
a coach this week and a special
meeting of the Athletic Board will
be called to make the appointment.
As soon as these matters have
been settled practice will begin.
Candidates will be called to the organization meeting, which soon will
be held in the Trophy Room of the
cage and be registered. The team
has suffered some losses through
graduation, but a number of new
men with diamond experience have
entered. The main weakness lies in
the pitching staff, only one experienced twirler having remained.
He is Jack Defandorf, who beat St.
John's last year. Eggie Gorman,
although never a 'Varsity moundsman, will be a candidate and may
land a regular job.
The catching department will be
strong, having Noble, last year's
St. John's backstop; Martindale,
formerly of Yale, and Charlie
Tinges, next season's football manager. Last year Hopkins was weak
in this department, Hub Rice being
the only reliable backstop.
Frank Worthington, formerly a
Princeton star, will be with the
squad again this season, as will
Lednum, Defandorf, Porter, Bagley, McDowell, Pitt, Hilgartner,
John Dorsey, Richardson and Steinbach. Butts Sutton, goal of former
lacrosse teams, has served his four
years at that sport and will try for
a position on the nine. New men
are Egerton, Alec Randall, Frank
Ford, Bobby France and Joe Branham.

"RAGTIME EXPRESSMAN' MAKES
BOW AS PIANIST AT DANCE

An informal dance was held by
a number of students in the Trophy
Room last Thursday afternoon at
four o'clock. The affair was entirely
unpremeditated, but was heartily
enjoyed by those who happened to
attend.
One of the leading pianists of the
Glee Club was running over a
dreamy reminiscence of Chopin during the afternoon, when the drowsy
strains penetrated through the open
windows and into the campus below. It happened that the American Express Company was in the
act of delivering some packages to
the University postoffice, as a large
automobile truck stood below, with
the usual .blue-shirted attendant.
This was a very ordinary looking
young man—nothing at all out of
the usual run of human beings.
But when Chopin reached his
sensitive ears, he started, turned,
and dashed into the gymnasium
door, rushed up stairs, removed the
"high-brow" manipulator of the
piano, and seating himself with a
gesture worthy of Irving Berlin at
his very worst, proceeded to pound
out ragtime, the real, unadulturated,
genuine article, with the art of the
Seidenmann brothers in his every
blow at the piano.
Naturally these furtive melodies
drew the crowd, and the dance
which followed was marked by a
great deal of exquisite pas seul
work.
It has been suggested that the
"Ragtime Expressman" be offered
the position of honor which "Louie"
now holds in McCoy Hall seances.
His touch was really masterly. He
played, as J. 0. L. would say, with
elan and supreme authority.

PRICE, FIVE CENTS
SWIMMING TEAM GETS BUSY
Independent Tank Artists Have Scheduled Dual Meets and Hold Regular
Practices—Rowland Captain.

The independent swimming team,
which has been projected for over
a month, took a definite form at an
organization meeting held Wednesday. While not recognized by the
Athletic Association, the team will
encounter no opposition from it—
non-recognition meaning only that
no funds are voted for the swimmers' support and that they may
not be designated as official athletic
representatives of the University.
Three officers were elected for
the year. Henry A. Rowland was
chosen captain, with Wilmer Brinton as leader of the water polo
forces, if the material available justifies the organization of such a
team. Dorsey Richardson was selected as manager and will proceed
in arranging a schedule, which it is
hoped will include several large college aquatic aggregations as well
as the leading teams of the city and
State. Negotiations have been
opened with Swarthmore and Pennsylvania, and Princeton, Navy and
possibly another college will be approached in a few days.
The first meet will probably be
with City College within two weeks,
in order that the team may have
practice in competition before tackling any very formidable opponent.
Marston's and Polytechnic may be
on the schedule in practice affairs.
The first practice took place last
Saturday morning in the Central
Young Men's Christian Association
pool and was well attended. However, Captain Rowland wants more
men to come out, as there are several places none too well filled and
an excellent opportunity is afforded
freshmen to make the team. The
220 and the plunge are the most
obvious weaknesses at present.
Practices will be held every Wednesday evening from 8 to 9 o'clock
in the Young Men's Christian Association pool and every Saturday
morning from 11.30 to 12.30.
The candidates for the swimming
and water polo teams who have reported so far are: Rowland, D.
Woodward, H. Woodward, Hoffman, W. J. Fulton, Brinton, Bagley, Richardson, Primrose, Johnson,
Tinges, Gorman, Bartlett, Wood,
Eiseman and'Penniman.
Vanilla Fellowship at Michigan.

A fellowship carrying a stipend
of five hundred dollars has been established this year at the University
of Michigan by the Flavoring Extract Manufacturers' Association
for an independent authoritative
scientific study of the manufacture
and analysis of vanilla extract.

Large Variety of Caps

The time for those functions of
convival felicity and good fellowship, the class banquets, is rapidly
approaching. Although no definite
plans have been made, the president of each class has appointed a
banquet committee.
The 1915 Class, in accordance
with their reputation for originality
and cleverness, expect this year to
hold a "Logic Banquet." It is
hoped that this will be as interesting as the "Physics Banquet" of
last year, and the "Canterbury Banquet" of the year before. The
senior committee consists of J. S.
Short, chairman; E. R. Spencer,
I.. R. Ford, Jack DeWitt, N. C.
Lindau.
President John Knipp of the
juniors announces that his class
proposes to hold an unusual dinner,
which will be in charge of the following committee:
Hiram Woodward, chairman;
Thomas T. Tingley, Myron Bagley, Dorsey Richardson, Clarence
McDowell.
The committee to arrange the
sophomore banquet is: H. J. Gorman, chairman, W. J. Fulton, T.
Binford, F. P. Hall, J. T. Thompson.
The freshman committee: Page
Nelson, chairman; Alec Wolf and
Stewart Egerton.
The senior plans have not assumed definite form, but it is probable that the banquet will be given
on a night in the second week of
February. Immediately will follow
the junior "feed," and the lower
classes will come in order.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS—LETTER, JANUARY 11, 1915.
CAN YOU HELP THE BELGIANS?
Hopkins Has Not Responded as It Should
to Appeals for Clothes and Money to
Be Sent to Stricken Refugees.

Although no effort to revive the
movement whose object was the relief of suffering incident to the present war in Europe was made immediately after the holidays by the
committee in charge of the campaign, Chairman Sutton has to report the receipt of several contributions in money and some clothes to
be devoted to this worthy cause. He
is extremely anxious to receive further donations as soon as possible,
and hopes that all undergraduates
who are interested in the proposed
work will contribute generously and
enthusiastically during the coming
week.
While the committee is pleased at
'the spirited co-operation lent by
many members of the student body,
it is nevertheless disappointed at the
general lack of interest in an undertaking that closely concerns every
man at the University. Surely
more men than the comparative few
who have up to the present time
responded to the call are able and
would, if they would only go to the
trouble of giving the matter serious
consideration, be anxious to lend
their material support to so timely
and so praiseworthy a movement as
that of relieving the suffering prevalent in Belgium. The donation of
an old suit of clothes, or of even a
very small amount of money, would
do much to make the work of the
Hopkins committee a success and to
show that the undergraduates at
the University are ready to stand
enthusiastically behind any movement of general interest that may
be inaugurated.
There is no logical reason why
Gettysburg and Western Maryland
should surpass Hopkins in the widespread interest displayed in just
such a campaign as the one that has
been suggested here. Surely our
students should be too jealous of
the good name of the University to
allow any movement which has been
a success elsewhere to meet with
comparative failure at our own institution. A very little consideration and manifestation of interest
on the part of the student body will
he sufficient to make the local campaign a success. It is sincerely to
be hoped that during the next week
every class and every individual
man at the University will do something to help along the Hopkins
"Belgian Fund."
Helfrich Leads in Chess Contest.

Much enthusiasm is being displayed by the participants in the
chess tournament which is now in
progress. About half of the games
have been played and the contest
appears very close. Helfrich is
leading in games won and Gutman
in games lost. The winner will
probably be Helfrich, Hammond or
Sacks.

1916 Hullabaloo Men at Work.

While the attention of most of
the undergraduates at the University is centered on reports of the
progress being made in the preparation of the 1915 Hullabaloo, the
members of the 1916 Board have
been engaged in considering questions relating to the publication of
their own year book and in gathering material.
Most of the work done up to the
present time has been accomplished
by special committees appointed for
the purpose, but a meeting will be
held in the near future and an art
manager selected from among contestants. An advertising manager
may also be chosen at this meeting,
although it is more probable that
his selection will be postponed until
a later time.
The business department of the
Board, headed by Manager M. E.
Bagley, is at present keeping in
touch with the work being done by
those who are interested in problems of managing the advertising
and of looking after the financial
end of the 1915 Hullabaloo. In
this way it will be possible for them
to acquire information concerning
the proper carrying out of such details and also to become acquainted
with advertisers.
Class Debate Arrangements Concluded.

Arrangements for the a n n tt al
senior-junior debate, to be held in
the Assembly Hall on the evening
of Friday, January 29, have been
completed and both teams are now
engaged in preparing for the contest.
Fate has so far been favorable to
the cause of the third-year men, as
they won the toss that determined
the selection of sides, and chose to
defend the negative of the question,
"Resolved, That a policy of colonial
expansion is advisable for the modern State." This subject was also
chosen by Virginia, North Carolina
and Hopkins for this year's triangular debate.
The men on the teams are at
present confronted with the necessity of gaining by extensive reading
a general knowledge of the question to be discussed. Briefs will
then be drawn up and the arguments decided upon assigned to the
several speakers for inclusion in
their addresses. Dr. John C.
French, of the English Department, will supervise this work and
keep in close touch with the plans
and arrangements of the opposing
teams.
The interclass debate is being
held unusually early in the season
this year in order that the teams
representing the University may be
given more time for the strengthening of their attack and defense before meeting the representatives of
rival institutions.

JOHN N. MATTHEWS CO.

The lacrosse squad has now begun daily practices in preparation
for the alumni game, scheduled for
March 27. The coaches have heretofore been rather lax with the men
in regard to attendance, but now
Coach Raney Wolfe wants it known
that it is imperative that all men
out for the team must report more
regularly, especially on Wednesday
and Saturday, when the entire
squad works out in the cage.
Scrimmages are now a feature
of the practices. The squad is divided into two teams, with the lineup changed from ,time to time in
order to give the new men a better
chance to display their ability.
There are a number of lacrosse
players on the squad that entered
the University from City College
who are showing up particularly
well. Among these are Alec Wolfe,
F. Sutton, R. Hoffman and R.
Woodward.
Lacrosse practice in the cage was
held during the Christmas holidays.
However, it is realized that with
only two months left to round out
a championship team there is much
hard work ahead for the squad.
Captain Tom Troxell especially emphasizes the need of defensive men.
The squad has been materially
weakened in this department

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS—LETTER, JANUARY 11, 1915.

DR.ESTHER VAN DEMAN TOLD OF

SOPHOMORE-FRESHMAN TRACK

ROMAN OUTPOSTS IN N. AFRICA

MEET PLANNED FOR JAN. 23

A lecture was given in McCoy
Hall Friday which was noteworthy
for two reasons—the lecturer and
the lecture. The lecturer was Dr.
Esther Boise van Deman; the lecture was on "Roman Outposts in
North Africa."
Dr. van Deman is among the
most noted living archaeologists.
She resides at Rome, Italy, and is
connected with the Reasearch Association in Roman Archaeology of
the Carnegie Institute of Washington. Hopkins men should be especially interested in the work of
this famous excavator, for she is
the aunt of a member of the Hopkins staff—Dr. Ralph van Deman
Magoffin.
Incidentally, on the third floor of
McCoy Hall, can be found a joint
donation bearing the names of Dr.
van Deman and Dr. Magoffin.
The speaker was introduced by
Dr. Gildersleeve, who spoke in
glowing terms of the lecturer and
her work.
Dr. van Deman spoke well and
interestingly. A series of lantern
slides helped to make the various
points of her lecture. Clean-cut
views of ancient Roman relics of
Africa were shown.
First a brief sketch of the rise
and overthrow of Carthage was
given, followed by an account of
the Roman subjugation of the province of Africa. It was shown
how, setting their backs to the sea,
the Romans gradually worked their
-way inward, founding, as they
went, garrisons and cities, whose
ruins today furnish the only marks
we have of the Roman conquest.
Some remarkable pictures of
ancient arches and amphitheatres
were shown. In fact, one of the
Roman amphitheatres discovered in
Africa is the third largest of its
size which has been found. Fallen
bridges and stones once used in
Roman capitals were shown at close
range.
In the course of her lecture Dr.
van Deman exhibited some exceedingly remarkable pictures of the
latest excavated Roman treasure—
the Venus of Sarana. She also appealed to all Americans travelling
abroad to protest against the renovations of ruins by the French, in
order tce. preserve these historical
remnants in all their purity.
Another point of interest in the
lecture was the showing of some
pictures of the city of Biskra, where
Robert Hitchins laid some of the
scenes of his famous play "The
Garden of Allah."

Fred P. Hall, manager of the
1917 track team, and William H.
Swartz, manager of the 1918 track
team, have started making arrangements for the annual track meet between the freshmen and sophomore
classes. January 23, has been proposed as a tentative date, although,
in all probability, the meet will not
come off until early in February.
The meet will be held in the cage,
and the regular indoor events will
be run off.
The sophomores are especially
well represented this year, having
many of the 'Varsity stars in the
class, and they are hoping to repeat their victory of a year ago.
The 1917 squad is composed of:
Binford (captain), F. Hall (manager), Straus,. Thompson, Dempster, Jacobs, Darley, Fulton, Sutton, G. Hall, Chesley, Rusk, Gorman, Weech, Bower, Perkins, Watson, Firor, Brooks, Keiser, Hobelman and Twigg.
Although they realize the strength
of the sophomores, the freshmen
are not discouraged. Manager
Swartz has been busy taking the
names of those who desire to uphold the honor of the class of 1918.
A partial list follows: Swartz
(manager), Wiggins, Edgett, Jarrett, Clark, Fisher, Golder, Kauffman, Rosenau, Gillet, Hoffman,
Taylor, Warner, Wolfe, Sutton,
Norman, Dodson, Jacobs, Egerton, Speed, Woodward, Thurman,
Roach, Levy, Konze, Johnson, Ewing, Rolker, Connoly and Duncan.
The captain has not yet been selected.
The rival classes are also looking forward to the lacrosse game
next spring. The freshmen are
strong in this sport and are likely
to add, to their victory in football,
a class lacrosse victory.

Princeton Shoe Shop.

Under the management of three
Princeton students a shoeshine shop
has been established on the Princeton campus. The work done in the
second term of 1912-13 totaled $1,050. The shop is completely under
student control. Four Italians are
employed to do the work.

Coming University Lectures.

Some interesting lectures will be
delivered at Hopkins in the near
future. On January i i Dr. Kuno
Meyer, professor of Celtic philology arid literature in the Universities of Berlin and Liverpool, will
lecture on "Ancient Irish Poetry,"
and on January 12 on "The Races
and Languages of Great Britain
and Ireland."
On January 16 and 23 Count
Wierzibicki will speak on "La
Frontiere du Rhin" in the Donovan Room. His lecture will be
delivered under the auspices of the
Alliance Francaise.
On the night of Wednesday,
January 13, Dr. C. M. Campbell
will speak in the physical laboratory
on "Social Service and Mental Disorders."

BOB LAYfIELD TAKEN HOME

BASEBALL PLANS ARE LAID
NEW TEAM ADVISERS

Varsity Quarterback With Broken Back
Removed From Hopkins Hospital
to "His Own Room at Home."

Committee in Charge of This Sport
Met Friday to Approve Schedule and
Talk Over Selection of Coach.

"Plucky Bob," the 'Varsity quarterback whose spinal cord was
broken in the football game with
Lehigh last October, was removed
from the Johns Hopkins Hospital
Thursday night to his home in Wilmington, Del.
For weeks it has been his most
cherished hope that he might be
taken to his home, where he could
be constantly with his parents and
where, he felt, he could more effectively fight the battle for his life.
Dr. Roland T. Abercrombie and
Dr. William S. Baer made a thorough examination of the game little
patient and decided that whenever
Bob wanted to he might safely
make the journey to Wilmington.
And so, in accordance with the
wishes of Bob and his parents, the
trip was started almost immediately. The patient was carried on
his bed to the hospital automobile
ambulance and, accompanied by Dr.
Abercrombie and Mr. Layfield, was
driven carefully to Union Station.
Here Bob and his bed were put
in a baggage car. The train left
at 8.10 P. M., and though every
jolt and turn of the hour and a
half's ride must have been felt by
the patient, Bob was the most
cheerful person in the party. The
thought that he was going home
was enough to keep up his spirits
and to help him endure the hardships of the journey.
Dr. Abercrombie said, in speaking of the trip to Wilmington:"Mr.
Layfield and I accompanied Bob on
the journey to Wilmington. He
stood the trip as well as could be
expected of one in his condition.
Although there is practically no
hope for his recovery, Bob and his
whole family have kept up the most
remarkable spirit I have ever seen.
Not one of them has shown a sign
that he has given up hope, or that
he has any intention of doing anything but keeping up a good spirit
and fighting to help Bob live.
"Such spirit and gameness as Bob
has shown in his remarkable struggle for existence deserves the highest reward, and to Bob that reward
would be life itself. And now, as
he lies in his own room, there with
him lie the prayers and sympathies
of every Hopkins student and of
every one of his host of friends in
Baltimore."
Bob had been in a room in the
Marburg Building of Johns Hopkins Hospital since November 3.
At first it was thought that he never
would have enough strength to be
removed, but a surprising courage
and reserve strength permitted the

'Varsity Baseball Committee
met Friday afternoon in the Hopkins Club to make plans for the
coming season. The schedule and
the matter of selecting a coach were
the chief topics discussed by the
Board, which is composed of Dr.
Thomas R. Brown, Dr. Robert B.
Roulston and Attorney Robertson
Griswold, alumni advisors; Dr.
Ronald T. Abercrombie, director of
athletics; Capt. C. C. Porter, Graduate Manager G. E. Dorsey and
Manager J. S. Short.
Eight or nine games will be
played this spring, the first being
with Princeton on April i at Homewood. In addition, most of the
State college teams will be met.
Contests also will be booked with
Swarthmore and University of
Pittsburgh. Nearly all of the games
will be on Saturday at Homewood,
only one trip being in view at this
time. The tentative schedule drawn
up by the manager was approved
and will be completed within the
next two weeks.
The committee decided to select
a coach this week and a special
meeting of the Athletic Board will
be called to make the appointment.
As soon as these matters have
been settled practice will begin.
Candidates will be called to the organization meeting, which soon will
be held in the Trophy Room of the
cage and be registered. The team
has suffered some losses through
graduation, but a number of new
men with diamond experience have
entered. The main weakness lies in
the pitching staff, only one experienced twirler having remained.
He is Jack Defandorf, who beat St.
John's last year. Eggie Gorman,
although never a 'Varsity moundsman, will be a candidate and may
land a regular job.
The catching department will be
strong, having Noble, last year's
St. John's backstop; Martindale,
formerly of Yale, and Charlie
Tinges, next season's football manager. Last year Hopkins was weak
in this department, Hub Rice being
the only reliable backstop.
Frank Worthington, formerly a
Princeton star, will be with the
squad again this season, as will
Lednum, Defandorf, Porter, Bagley, McDowell, Pitt, Hilgartner,
John Dorsey, Richardson and Steinbach. Butts Sutton, goal of former
lacrosse teams, has served his four
years at that sport and will try for
a position on the nine. New men
are Egerton, Alec Randall, Frank
Ford, Bobby France and Joe Branham.

"RAGTIME EXPRESSMAN' MAKES
BOW AS PIANIST AT DANCE

An informal dance was held by
a number of students in the Trophy
Room last Thursday afternoon at
four o'clock. The affair was entirely
unpremeditated, but was heartily
enjoyed by those who happened to
attend.
One of the leading pianists of the
Glee Club was running over a
dreamy reminiscence of Chopin during the afternoon, when the drowsy
strains penetrated through the open
windows and into the campus below. It happened that the American Express Company was in the
act of delivering some packages to
the University postoffice, as a large
automobile truck stood below, with
the usual .blue-shirted attendant.
This was a very ordinary looking
young man—nothing at all out of
the usual run of human beings.
But when Chopin reached his
sensitive ears, he started, turned,
and dashed into the gymnasium
door, rushed up stairs, removed the
"high-brow" manipulator of the
piano, and seating himself with a
gesture worthy of Irving Berlin at
his very worst, proceeded to pound
out ragtime, the real, unadulturated,
genuine article, with the art of the
Seidenmann brothers in his every
blow at the piano.
Naturally these furtive melodies
drew the crowd, and the dance
which followed was marked by a
great deal of exquisite pas seul
work.
It has been suggested that the
"Ragtime Expressman" be offered
the position of honor which "Louie"
now holds in McCoy Hall seances.
His touch was really masterly. He
played, as J. 0. L. would say, with
elan and supreme authority.

PRICE, FIVE CENTS
SWIMMING TEAM GETS BUSY
Independent Tank Artists Have Scheduled Dual Meets and Hold Regular
Practices—Rowland Captain.

The independent swimming team,
which has been projected for over
a month, took a definite form at an
organization meeting held Wednesday. While not recognized by the
Athletic Association, the team will
encounter no opposition from it—
non-recognition meaning only that
no funds are voted for the swimmers' support and that they may
not be designated as official athletic
representatives of the University.
Three officers were elected for
the year. Henry A. Rowland was
chosen captain, with Wilmer Brinton as leader of the water polo
forces, if the material available justifies the organization of such a
team. Dorsey Richardson was selected as manager and will proceed
in arranging a schedule, which it is
hoped will include several large college aquatic aggregations as well
as the leading teams of the city and
State. Negotiations have been
opened with Swarthmore and Pennsylvania, and Princeton, Navy and
possibly another college will be approached in a few days.
The first meet will probably be
with City College within two weeks,
in order that the team may have
practice in competition before tackling any very formidable opponent.
Marston's and Polytechnic may be
on the schedule in practice affairs.
The first practice took place last
Saturday morning in the Central
Young Men's Christian Association
pool and was well attended. However, Captain Rowland wants more
men to come out, as there are several places none too well filled and
an excellent opportunity is afforded
freshmen to make the team. The
220 and the plunge are the most
obvious weaknesses at present.
Practices will be held every Wednesday evening from 8 to 9 o'clock
in the Young Men's Christian Association pool and every Saturday
morning from 11.30 to 12.30.
The candidates for the swimming
and water polo teams who have reported so far are: Rowland, D.
Woodward, H. Woodward, Hoffman, W. J. Fulton, Brinton, Bagley, Richardson, Primrose, Johnson,
Tinges, Gorman, Bartlett, Wood,
Eiseman and'Penniman.
Vanilla Fellowship at Michigan.

A fellowship carrying a stipend
of five hundred dollars has been established this year at the University
of Michigan by the Flavoring Extract Manufacturers' Association
for an independent authoritative
scientific study of the manufacture
and analysis of vanilla extract.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS—LETTER, JANUARY 11, 1915.
CAN YOU HELP THE BELGIANS?
Hopkins Has Not Responded as It Should
to Appeals for Clothes and Money to
Be Sent to Stricken Refugees.

Although no effort to revive the
movement whose object was the relief of suffering incident to the present war in Europe was made immediately after the holidays by the
committee in charge of the campaign, Chairman Sutton has to report the receipt of several contributions in money and some clothes to
be devoted to this worthy cause. He
is extremely anxious to receive further donations as soon as possible,
and hopes that all undergraduates
who are interested in the proposed
work will contribute generously and
enthusiastically during the coming
week.
While the committee is pleased at
'the spirited co-operation lent by
many members of the student body,
it is nevertheless disappointed at the
general lack of interest in an undertaking that closely concerns every
man at the University. Surely
more men than the comparative few
who have up to the present time
responded to the call are able and
would, if they would only go to the
trouble of giving the matter serious
consideration, be anxious to lend
their material support to so timely
and so praiseworthy a movement as
that of relieving the suffering prevalent in Belgium. The donation of
an old suit of clothes, or of even a
very small amount of money, would
do much to make the work of the
Hopkins committee a success and to
show that the undergraduates at
the University are ready to stand
enthusiastically behind any movement of general interest that may
be inaugurated.
There is no logical reason why
Gettysburg and Western Maryland
should surpass Hopkins in the widespread interest displayed in just
such a campaign as the one that has
been suggested here. Surely our
students should be too jealous of
the good name of the University to
allow any movement which has been
a success elsewhere to meet with
comparative failure at our own institution. A very little consideration and manifestation of interest
on the part of the student body will
he sufficient to make the local campaign a success. It is sincerely to
be hoped that during the next week
every class and every individual
man at the University will do something to help along the Hopkins
"Belgian Fund."
Helfrich Leads in Chess Contest.

Much enthusiasm is being displayed by the participants in the
chess tournament which is now in
progress. About half of the games
have been played and the contest
appears very close. Helfrich is
leading in games won and Gutman
in games lost. The winner will
probably be Helfrich, Hammond or
Sacks.

1916 Hullabaloo Men at Work.

While the attention of most of
the undergraduates at the University is centered on reports of the
progress being made in the preparation of the 1915 Hullabaloo, the
members of the 1916 Board have
been engaged in considering questions relating to the publication of
their own year book and in gathering material.
Most of the work done up to the
present time has been accomplished
by special committees appointed for
the purpose, but a meeting will be
held in the near future and an art
manager selected from among contestants. An advertising manager
may also be chosen at this meeting,
although it is more probable that
his selection will be postponed until
a later time.
The business department of the
Board, headed by Manager M. E.
Bagley, is at present keeping in
touch with the work being done by
those who are interested in problems of managing the advertising
and of looking after the financial
end of the 1915 Hullabaloo. In
this way it will be possible for them
to acquire information concerning
the proper carrying out of such details and also to become acquainted
with advertisers.
Class Debate Arrangements Concluded.

Arrangements for the a n n tt al
senior-junior debate, to be held in
the Assembly Hall on the evening
of Friday, January 29, have been
completed and both teams are now
engaged in preparing for the contest.
Fate has so far been favorable to
the cause of the third-year men, as
they won the toss that determined
the selection of sides, and chose to
defend the negative of the question,
"Resolved, That a policy of colonial
expansion is advisable for the modern State." This subject was also
chosen by Virginia, North Carolina
and Hopkins for this year's triangular debate.
The men on the teams are at
present confronted with the necessity of gaining by extensive reading
a general knowledge of the question to be discussed. Briefs will
then be drawn up and the arguments decided upon assigned to the
several speakers for inclusion in
their addresses. Dr. John C.
French, of the English Department, will supervise this work and
keep in close touch with the plans
and arrangements of the opposing
teams.
The interclass debate is being
held unusually early in the season
this year in order that the teams
representing the University may be
given more time for the strengthening of their attack and defense before meeting the representatives of
rival institutions.

ROMAN OUTPOSTS IN N. AFRICA

MEET PLANNED FOR JAN. 23

A lecture was given in McCoy
Hall Friday which was noteworthy
for two reasons—the lecturer and
the lecture. The lecturer was Dr.
Esther Boise van Deman; the lecture was on "Roman Outposts in
North Africa."
Dr. van Deman is among the
most noted living archaeologists.
She resides at Rome, Italy, and is
connected with the Reasearch Association in Roman Archaeology of
the Carnegie Institute of Washington. Hopkins men should be especially interested in the work of
this famous excavator, for she is
the aunt of a member of the Hopkins staff—Dr. Ralph van Deman
Magoffin.
Incidentally, on the third floor of
McCoy Hall, can be found a joint
donation bearing the names of Dr.
van Deman and Dr. Magoffin.
The speaker was introduced by
Dr. Gildersleeve, who spoke in
glowing terms of the lecturer and
her work.
Dr. van Deman spoke well and
interestingly. A series of lantern
slides helped to make the various
points of her lecture. Clean-cut
views of ancient Roman relics of
Africa were shown.
First a brief sketch of the rise
and overthrow of Carthage was
given, followed by an account of
the Roman subjugation of the province of Africa. It was shown
how, setting their backs to the sea,
the Romans gradually worked their
-way inward, founding, as they
went, garrisons and cities, whose
ruins today furnish the only marks
we have of the Roman conquest.
Some remarkable pictures of
ancient arches and amphitheatres
were shown. In fact, one of the
Roman amphitheatres discovered in
Africa is the third largest of its
size which has been found. Fallen
bridges and stones once used in
Roman capitals were shown at close
range.
In the course of her lecture Dr.
van Deman exhibited some exceedingly remarkable pictures of the
latest excavated Roman treasure—
the Venus of Sarana. She also appealed to all Americans travelling
abroad to protest against the renovations of ruins by the French, in
order tce. preserve these historical
remnants in all their purity.
Another point of interest in the
lecture was the showing of some
pictures of the city of Biskra, where
Robert Hitchins laid some of the
scenes of his famous play "The
Garden of Allah."

Fred P. Hall, manager of the
1917 track team, and William H.
Swartz, manager of the 1918 track
team, have started making arrangements for the annual track meet between the freshmen and sophomore
classes. January 23, has been proposed as a tentative date, although,
in all probability, the meet will not
come off until early in February.
The meet will be held in the cage,
and the regular indoor events will
be run off.
The sophomores are especially
well represented this year, having
many of the 'Varsity stars in the
class, and they are hoping to repeat their victory of a year ago.
The 1917 squad is composed of:
Binford (captain), F. Hall (manager), Straus,. Thompson, Dempster, Jacobs, Darley, Fulton, Sutton, G. Hall, Chesley, Rusk, Gorman, Weech, Bower, Perkins, Watson, Firor, Brooks, Keiser, Hobelman and Twigg.
Although they realize the strength
of the sophomores, the freshmen
are not discouraged. Manager
Swartz has been busy taking the
names of those who desire to uphold the honor of the class of 1918.
A partial list follows: Swartz
(manager), Wiggins, Edgett, Jarrett, Clark, Fisher, Golder, Kauffman, Rosenau, Gillet, Hoffman,
Taylor, Warner, Wolfe, Sutton,
Norman, Dodson, Jacobs, Egerton, Speed, Woodward, Thurman,
Roach, Levy, Konze, Johnson, Ewing, Rolker, Connoly and Duncan.
The captain has not yet been selected.
The rival classes are also looking forward to the lacrosse game
next spring. The freshmen are
strong in this sport and are likely
to add, to their victory in football,
a class lacrosse victory.

Princeton Shoe Shop.

Under the management of three
Princeton students a shoeshine shop
has been established on the Princeton campus. The work done in the
second term of 1912-13 totaled $1,050. The shop is completely under
student control. Four Italians are
employed to do the work.

Coming University Lectures.

Some interesting lectures will be
delivered at Hopkins in the near
future. On January i i Dr. Kuno
Meyer, professor of Celtic philology arid literature in the Universities of Berlin and Liverpool, will
lecture on "Ancient Irish Poetry,"
and on January 12 on "The Races
and Languages of Great Britain
and Ireland."
On January 16 and 23 Count
Wierzibicki will speak on "La
Frontiere du Rhin" in the Donovan Room. His lecture will be
delivered under the auspices of the
Alliance Francaise.
On the night of Wednesday,
January 13, Dr. C. M. Campbell
will speak in the physical laboratory
on "Social Service and Mental Disorders."

President Goodnow and Dr.
Westel W. Willoughby, professor
of political science, attended the annual meeting of the American Political Science Association in Chicago during the Christmas vacation.
President Goodnow spent part of
the holidays in New York visiting
his son and on December 29 went
to Chicago. Dr. Willoughby, after
the meeting in Chicago, spent a few
days in Dubuque, Ia., before returning to Baltimore.
